summary: coronaviruses HCoV-OC43, HCoV-229E, HCoV-NL63 and HCoV-HKU1 circulate in humans and cause mild respiratory diseases. the outbreak of SARS-CoV in 2002 and MERS-CoV in 2012 showed that coronaviruses can cross the species barrier and emerge as highly pathogenic viruses. the high fatality rate and wide spread of these new emerging coronaviruses indicate that they are a the fusion subunit undergoes large-scale conformational rearrangements to expose the hydrophobic fusion peptide. the cleavage site of the SARS-CoV S glycoprotein is located after residue 667 of the precursor protein. the S2’ cleavage site of the SARS-CoV S glycoprotein is highly conserved among coronaviruses. a recently reported cryo-EM structure of the MHV S glycoprotein in its postfusion state shows an elongated cone-shaped structure that is significantly different from the prefusion structure. the prefusion SARS-CoV S1 subunit is structurally organized into four distinct domains: NTD, CTD1, CTD2 and CTD3 [13]. similar observations of a protruding “up” CTD1 have also been reported for MERS-CoV S glycoproteins [7, cryo-EM analysis of the cleaved S glycoprotein showed an intact trimer in both the neutral-pH (pH 7.2) and the low-pH (pH 5.6) buffer. the maps are consistent with the prefusion S trimer structure previously determined using the Arg667Ala mutant. the complex was then prepared using trypsin-cleaved and low-pH-treated S glycoprotein and ACE2. three conformational states of the complex were captured and determined at resolutions of 5.4, 4.2 and 4.5. ACE2-bound states showed that the SARS-CoV S glycoprotein binds one ACE2 receptor utilizing only the “up” CTD1. the structure of the other ACE2-free state was determined at a resolution of 3.9. this conformation was designated as the unbound-up conformation, which is ready for receptor binding. the structure of the other ACE2-free state was determined at a resolution of 3.6. ACE2-free spikes Simultaneous observation of the ACE2-bound, unbound-up and unbound-down conformations of the S glycoprotein in the trypsin- and low-pH-treated sample provided an opportunity to investigate possible conformational changes induced by receptor binding. a hinge motion away from the spike axis compared to CTD2 in the unbound-down conformation. Upon binding to the receptor ACE2, CTD2 exhibits a hinge motion away from the S2 stem. the fusion peptide is colored red and position of the S2’ site is indicated with black arrows. the “C” shape loop covering the S2’ site is colored blue. the cleavage site is inaccessible in both the unbound-down and the ACE2-bound SARS-CoV S glycoprotein structures. the uninterpreted density at one distal end of the dumbbell-shaped density map should be the exposed fusion peptide that is disordered. the cleavage site is not resolved and should be completely exposed based on the post-fusion SARS-CoV S2 structure model (S9C Fig). analysis of the S trimer structure in the prefusion state showed that the “C”-shaped loop (residues 787–796) covering the S2’ cleavage site was clipped by the linker downstream of the S1/S2 cleavage site of an adjacent protomer. disassociation of one S1-ACE2 complex from the spike would release the clipping linker. ACE2 and S1 densities are marked cyan and pink respectively. a 3D density map calculated from the particles of the S1-ACE2 peak in “A”. ACE2 and S1 densities are marked cyan and pink respectively. elution peaks were collected by gel-filtration chromatography. fractions containing the complex were subjected to EM analysis. cleaved S glycoprotein showed intact trimer in neutral-pH and low-pH buffer. three conformational states of the S-ACE2 complex were captured and determined at resolutions of 5.4, 4.2 and 4.5. two conformational states of the ACE2-free S glycoprotein were also determined at resolutions of 3.6 and 3.9. ACE2-bound states showed that the SARS-CoV S glycoprotein binds one ACE2 receptor utilizing only the “up” CTD1. Cryo-EM analysis showed similar ACE2-bound, unbound-up and unbound-down conformations. ACE2 and the trypsin-cleaved SARS-CoV S glycoprotein were tested without low-pH treatment. the angle for the CTD1s from the ACE2-bound conformations was approximately 22.7°. Approximately 19% of the ACE2-bound particles had their CTD1s open to 111.6°. this result indicates that receptor binding can open up CTD1. further comparisons were performed for CTD2, which is located underneath CTD1. binding to one ACE2 did not induce significant conformational changes in the stem region of the prefusion S glycoprotein. binding to one ACE2 did not induce significant conformational changes in the stem region of the prefusion S glycoprotein. the cleavage site is inaccessible in both the unbound-down and the ACE2-bound SARS-CoV S glycoprotein structures. neither the “down” to “up” conformational change of one CTD1 and its binding to one ACE receptor nor a decrease in the pH drive exposure of the S2’ cleavage site. scale bar: 50 nm. (C) 2D class averaged cryo-EM images of the SARS-CoV S2 in post-fusion state. the three protomers are colored pink, yellow and cyan, respectively. a similar size-exclusion chromatography profile and rosette-shaped particles in the EM image of the complex consisting of ACE2 and the trypsin-cleaved S glycoprotein without low-pH treatment. this finding indicates that low-pH treatment of the cleaved S glycoprotein is not required for the disassociation of S1-ACE2 or for the formation of rosette-shaped particles. ACE2 and S1 densities are marked cyan and pink, respectively. the flexible NTD and CTD3 are not visible and are represented as an ellipse. the linker downstream the S1/S2 cleavage site is colored green. cleavage at the S1/S2 site is required for a functional S glycoprotein. similar results were obtained for the cleaved with/without low-pH treatment S glycoproteins. the conformational heterogeneity of CTD1s still exists. a conformational switch producing more than one “up” CTD1 may destabilize the cleaved S glycoprotein and trigger immediate disassociation of the S1 subunits and the S1-ACE2 complex. the prefusion S2 subunits are a six-helix bundle with a 160-long central helix core. the “down” CTD1s are located immediately above the S2 subunits. the direct contact should stabilize the prefusion S2 subunit and prevent it from transitioning into the postfusion state. opening of CTD1, especially by binding the receptor, would remove the steric restraints on helix linker 2, triggering the release of the S1 subunits. binding to ACE2 opens up CTD1 and CTD2 promotes disassociation of the S1-ACE2 complex from the S1/S2 cleaved S glycoprotein. binding to ACE2 opens up CTD1 and CTD2 and initiates membrane fusion. the cell culture was collected by centrifugation at 48 hours post infection. the supernatant was concentrated, loaded into nickel (Ni)-charged resin (GE Healthcare), eluted with 0.5 M imidazole in Buffer A (50 mM Tris, pH 8.8, 40 mM NaCl) and then purified using an increase Superdex 200 column pre-equilibrated with Buffer A. the cleaved S protein was mixed with ACE2 at a molar ratio of 1:3. then the mixture was incubated at 4°C overnight. the mixture was purified by gel-filtration chromatography using an increase Superose 6 5/150 column (GE Healthcare) pre-equilibrated with HBS buffer. membrane was blocked for 1 hour at room temperature with a non-fat milk buffer. then incubated with mouse monoclonal anti-strep tag antibodies. then incubated with goat-anti-mouse IgG for 45 minutes at room temperature. images were collected using a Gatan 895 4 k 4 k CCD camera at a nominal magnification of 49,000 with a pixel size of 0.227 nm. images were recorded at a defocus range of -1.5 m to -4 m with a pixel size of 1.27. the exposure time was 1.2 s, with a total exposure dose of 60 electron. images of the ACE2 and cleaved and low-pH-treated S glycoprotein complex were collected using an FEI Titan Krios electron microscope. each image was dose-fractionated into 32 movie frames at a dose rate of 8.2 counts per physical pixel per second. each image was dose-fractionated into 32 movie frames at a dose rate of 8.2 counts per physical pixel per second. 688,289 selected particles were then subjected to 3D classification. a total of 241,551 particles were automatically selected using the Gautomacth program. a total of 241,551 particles were automatically selected using the Gautomacth program. the ACE2 atomic model (PDB ID: 2ajf) was converted into a density map using the python script e2pdb2mrc.py. the two reconstructions had a CC value of 0.88 (at a contouring level of 3) the consistency of the two reconstructions indicated that the reconstruction was reliable. a total of 34,149 particles were subjected to several rounds of 2D and 3D classification. initial model was generated by e2initialmodel.py using typical 2D class averages. the model was refined by using ROSETTA [35] and PHENIX with secondary structure restraints and geometry restraints. the unbound-down S model excluding the “up” CTD1 was fitted into the 3.9 density map as a rigid body. angles of the CTD1s, the horizontal plane of the S glycoprotein perpendicular to the 3-fold axis and the long axis of the “up” CTD1 were generated using the UCSF Chimera “define” command. the homologous model of the SARS-CoV S glycoprotein in postfusion state was calculated using the MHV S glycoprotein in the postfusion state. chromatography using increase Superdex 200 column (GE Healthcare) pre-equilibrated with HBS buffer (10 mM HEPES at pH 7.2, 150 mM NaCl) human ACE2 extracellular domain (residues 19–615) with an N-terminal gp67 signal peptide for secretion and a C-terminal 6 his tag for purification was inserted into a pFastBac-Duel vector cleaved SARS-CoV S glycoprotein was incubated at 18°C for 16 hours. mixed with trypsin at a mass ratio of 1:100 in 50 mM Tris-HCl at pH 8.0 with 20 mM CaCl2 at 18°C, for more than 16 hours. mixture was purified and verified by gel-filtration chromatography using an increase Superose 6 5/150 column. immunoblotting Uncleaved S glycoprotein, cleaved S glycoprotein, S1-ACE2 and ACE2 were prepared as previously described in this paper. the samples were mixed with loading buffer and boiled at 100°C for 10 minutes. the membrane was blocked for 1 hour at room temperature with a non-fat milk buffer and then incubated with mouse monoclonal anti-strep tag antibodies. 3 l aliquots of samples at a concentration of 0.02 mg/ml were applied onto a glow-discharged grid with a continuous carbon layer. the grid was immediately washed twice and incubated with 3 l of 1% uranyl acetate (UA) solution for an additional minute. the grid was then blotted with filter paper to remove UA, air-dried at room temperature, and examined under an FEI Tecnai Spirit glycoprotein, trypsin-cleaved and low-pH-treated S glycoprotein, and the complex of ACE2 and trypsin-cleaved S glycoprotein were collected in frame stacks using an FEI Tecnai Arctica electron microscope. images were recorded at a defocus range of -1.5 m to -4 m with a pixel size of 1.27. each image was dose-fractionated into 32 movie frames at a dose rate of 3D classifications and refinements were performed using the MOTIONCORR2 program [27] before further processing. 1,033,788 particles selected from 2,813 micrographs were subjected to several rounds of 2D classification. a total of 241,551 particles were automatically selected using the Gautomacth program. 2D and 3D classifications and refinements were performed using RELION 1.4. ACE2-bound S glycoprotein conformation 1, ACE2-bound S glycoprotein conformation 2, ACE2-bound S glycoprotein conformation 3, unbound-up S glycoprotein and unbound-down S glycoprotein. a total of 34,149 particles were subjected to several rounds of 2D and 3D classification. the reported resolutions are based on the gold-standard Fourier shell correlation (FSC) 0.143 criterion. local resolution variations were estimated using ResMap [33]. CCs between aligned maps were calculated using the UCSF Chimera “measure correlation” command. vector u contains the values of the first map and vector v contains the values of the second map. the horizontal plane of the S glycoprotein perpendicular to the 3-fold axis and the long axis of the “up” CTD1 were generated. analysis of the cleaved and uncleaved SARS-CoV S glycoprotein mutant R667A. representative 2D class averaged images of the cleaved and uncleaved SARS-CoV S glycoprotein. ACE2 binding monomer is colored red and the bound ACE2 is colored green. the angle between the long axes of the CTD1 and the horizontal plane is shown at the bottom of each structure. (4.8MB, tif) S8 Fig. EM densities of the CTD2s. from left to right: unbound-down CTD2 (contouring level: 8 ) and unbound-up CTD2 (contouring level: 8 ). the C backbone of the CTD2 is shown in each density map. gel filtration and negative staining analysis of the trypsin treated S and ACE2 complex at pH 7.2. four peaks were observed, similar to that of the low pH treated sample as in Fig 3A. no steric clash was observed for structure models in “B” and “C”. no steric clash was observed for structure models in “B” and “C”.
